item.title: Projects and Data Sets
item.description:
What is a Project / Data Set

Within the AMRcloud user can create various Projects and Data Sets.

Project is a structural element of the AMRcloud platform used to group several Data Sets at the user's discretion (you may view it as a folder).

Data Set is a basic unit within the Project that contains a discrete set of information that can be visualized and analyzed with the AMRcloud (you may view it as a separate file).

How to create a Project

To create a new Project in your personal account, press the + New Project button in the upper left corner of the screen.

Fill in the “New project name” and “Project subtitle” fields in the opening modal dialog (the limit is 255 characters).

It is strongly recommended to use unique and distinguishing names for your Projects (do not limit yourself to the names like “project1” or “project2”). The Project subtitle may include the keywords that further specify its content.

Types of projects

There are two types of Projects you can work with:

  • My Project
  • Team Project

My Project is a personal project.

Access to such Project is granted only to you, its creator and owner. However, you can share the results of analysis of project data with other users by generating external web links.

Team Project is a collective project.

Access to Team Progect is granted to several users appointed as members of a team. The user who has created a Team Project becomes its administrator and has the right to manage it (i.e. add, modify or remove Data Sets) and to invite other users registered in AMRcloud to become team members. The invited users can view shared projects under the “Team Projects” tab but can't manage them.

Data Sets

Within a Project you can create several Data Sets. To create a new Data Set, open the Project by clicking the “Open” button and then click the “+ New Set” button.

Fill in the “New set name” and “Set subtitle” fields in the opening modal dialog “Add New Set” (the limit is 255 characters).

It is strongly recommended to use unique and distinguishing names for your Data Sets (do not limit yourself to the names like “set1” or “set2”). The Data Set subtitle may include the keywords that further specify its content.

After creating a new Data Set, you can start uploading data to it by using the auto-opening wizard tool. Wizard can also be started at any time to modify the content of the existing Data Set by selecting it with left mouse click and then clicking the “Edit Set” button.

item.title: Data preparation
item.description:
The “Rules of Thumb” for Data Preparation

Accurate, well-formated and structured source data is essential for successful analysis using the AMRcloud platform.

The following “rules of thumb” should be followed to prepare the data:

  1. The source data table should include individual isolate records and NOT aggregated statistics. Each isolate record should be represented by a separate row in the table.
  2. All AST Data and Metadata should be organized in columns with each column representing only a single type of data (number, date, character string).
  3. The Metadata must include four mandatory columns: Isolate Identifier, Organism/Species Name, Organism Group, and Date. All other metadata (e.g. geographical data, resistance markers, etc.) is optional.
  4. The AST Data may be of three different types: minimum inhibitory concentrations (MICs), inhibition zone diameters, and susceptibility categories (S/I/R). Headers of the columns representing AST Data should contain a generic name of antimicrobial agent and one of the three suffixes ("_mic”, “_dd” or “_sir”) denoting each type of data.

Example Data

The basic requirements for the source data table are listed in the Read Me tab of the data import wizard. An example data file for use as a reference for data formatting can be downloaded from a link at the bottom of the Read Me page.

Basic Requirements

The data should be presented in the required format to be handled by AMRcloud.

  1. The data table should be flat (i.e. it should contain columns and rows with no additional separators, no hierarchical structures).
  2. The first row of the table must be a header row with column names.
  3. The table should contain four mandatory metadata columns (although the column names may be different):
  • Isolate Identifier (ID)
  • Organism/Species Name
  • Organism Group
  • Date

Isolate ID

Isolate ID can be any combination of alphanumeric characters, except special symbols (?,!,%$#><), and can be non-unique. Records (rows) with empty ID field are not imported.

Organism/Species Name

Only the official Latine binomial names should be used for microbial species. Abbreviations in the species names are not allowed. Proper genus and species names are automatically recognized to define susceptibility categories to antimicrobial agents using specific breakpoints.

Right:

Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae

Wrong:

S. aureus, S. pneumoniae

Organism Group

Any taxonomic or non-taxonomic, full or abbreviated names can be used to define Organism Groups, however the names shoud be consistent throughout the column. Grouping of organisms (species) is used for analyzing combined statistics (e.g. resistance prevalence) of several species.

Right:

Enterobacterales, Staphylococci, GN anaerobes, Enterobacterales, Staphylococci, GN anaerobes (all names are standardized)

Wrong:

Enterobact, Staph, Entbact, Staphylococci, GN anaerobes, Gram-neg anaerobes (names are not standardized)

Date

The import wizard can automatically detect and interpret various Date formats, however, the Date format must be consistent throughout the column. Records without a Date are not imported.

Right:

12.08.2018, 20.05.2017, 16.03.2014 (same format DD.MM.YYYY)

Wrong:

13.08.2018, 20/05/19, 03/16/2014 (inconsistent format DD.MM.YYYY, DD/MM/YYYY, MM/DD/YYYY)

AST Data

The following types of AST Data can be handled by AMRcloud:

  • Minimum Inhibitory Concentrations (MICs)
  • Disk Diffusion Inhibition Zone Diameters
  • Susceptibility Categories (S/I/R)

You can provide unlimited number of columns with AST Data for multiple antibiotics and can include data of different types for the same antibiotic in different columns.

Please strictly follow the rules below for naming the columns and choosing the format of AST Data entries.

Header of the columns containing AST Data must start with full generic name of antibiotic in English followed by the underscore symbol and must end with one of the three suffixes denoting the type of data:
Minimum Inhibitory Concentrations _mic
Disk Diffusion Inhibition Zone Diameters _dd
Susceptibility Categories _sir

Example:

tobramycin_sir, tetracycline_sir, amoxicillin-clavulanic acid_dd, vancomycin_mic

The list of legitimate antibiotic names can be downloaded from the link at the Read Me tab of the data import wizard. The quantitative AST Data (MIC and inhibition zone values) for the known antibiotics are automatically interpreted into susceptibility categories using selected criteria (breakpoints).

Note

Other (arbitrary) names of antimicrobial agents can be used in the column headers, however, quantitative AST Data for such agents are not translated into suceptibility categories. If you want to use alternative criteria (breakpoints) for certain antimicrobial agents, you can modify their names as shown in the examples below:

amoxicillin-clavulanic acid_clsi_mic, moxifloxacin_clsi_sir, marbofloxacin_veterinary_sir

The requirements for the format of AST Data entries are as follows:

  • Minimum Inhibitory Concentration Values

    • MIC values are measured in mg/L.
    • Values must be numeric.
    • Non-numeric values containing expressions “<=”, “>” or “>=” are automatically converted into numeric.
    • Symbols “<=” and “>=” preceding the numbers are removed.
    • Numbers preceded by “>” symbol are multiplied by two.

  • Disk Diffusion Inhibition Zone Diameter Values

    • Inhibition Zone Diameter values are measured in mm.
    • Values must be integers greater than or equal to six.

  • Susceptibility Category Values

    • The only allowed values are “S”, “I”, and “R”.
    • Values such as “S/I” or “I/R” are not allowed.

Additional Matadata

In addition to Mandatory Columns and AST Data, you table may include other optional columns with information about sources of isolates (including geospatial data), patient clinical and demographic data, specific characteristics of isolates (including phenotypic and genotypic resistance markers). These columns will be used as parameters for data selection, filtration and categorization.

Spatial Information Column(s)

Spatial Information includes geographic locations and, optionally, their coordinates (latitude and longitude). You may provide various types of objects as geolocations: countries, regions, states, natural areas, cities, smaller locality types or even detailed addresses (e.g. hospital buildings). At Step Three of the data import wizard, an automatic geocoding is performed to assign geographic coordinates to the known geolocations. You can also do it manually if automatic geocoding did not work.

If your data table already contains two columns with latitude and longitude values, you can check the box and then select these columns at Step One of the data import wizard.

Text (String) Metadata Columns

You can import a maximum of ten parameters (columns) containing text metadata (including the column with geographic names) to a single Data Set.

Numeric Metadata Column

You can import one parameter (column) containing continuous numeric variable such as “age”, “weight”, etc. Pleae note that if you use numeric parameter, all cells in the column must be filled in with the number, records (rows) with empty numeric field are not imported.

Resistance Markers Columns

Resistance Markers may represent any isolate characteristics (phenotypes or genotypes) that are relevant to antibiotic resistance. Markers can be assigned to groups with each Group of Markers set in a separate column. For example, the column with the header “ESBL” may contain the entries like: “CTX-M-15”, “TEM-3”, “SHV-2”, SHV-2+CTX-M-15, “ESBL-negative”, etc. You can provide unlimited number of columns with Resistance Markers.

To ensure consistency, the data on Resistance Markers can be presented as follows:

Results of testing for specific markers Entries
Positive results "OXA-48", "KPC", "CTX-M-15", "MRSA", "VRE" etc.
Negative result(s) "Negative"
Not tested "No data"
Not applicable for a particular organism/species empty cell

item.title: Step 1 - Upload Data
item.description:
Uploading a Data File

Please learn the content of the Read Me tab of the data import wizard first. To upload your data file to AMRcloud, go to the Step One tab, press the “Browse…" button and select the file. If the file content appears correctly in the preview pane, press the “Validate and Save Step One” button.

IMPORTANT!

  • AMRcloud supports .xlsx and .csv data files.
  • When uploading a .csv file, choose the format options from the “Options for csv file” panel to see the file content properly in the prevew pane.
  • Use the slider above the preview pane to customize the number rows (from 5 to 30) you want to preview.

Text Encoding Problems

If you notice character encoding problems in the uploaded data, open the source file with any suitable text editor and re-save it with the UTF-8 encoding, then re-upload the file to AMRcloud.

item.title: Step 2 - Set Fields
item.description:
At this stage for correct work of all analytical components of the AMRcloud platform user should correctly correlate the names of eight standard system categories with the columns from the uploaded data table.

On the left side of the screen there are standard categories (for example, “Isolate ID”, “Organism Group(s)") with basic information and requirements. On the right side of the screen there are panels with drop-down lists of table column headers, with which the user correlates system categories.

Isolate ID

  • This is a mandatory category.
  • Isolate ID can be any unique identifier that doesn't include special characters (?,!,%$#><)

Organism Group(s)

  • This is a desirable category.
  • Grouping of organisms (species) is useful for analyzing combined prevalence and AST data of several species.
  • Use any name(s) for organism group(s), taxonomic (e.g. Enterobacterales) or non-taxonomic (e.g. Anaerobes, Gramnegative).

Organism/Species Names

  • This is a mandatory category.
  • Use Latinized binomial names acoording to official nomenclature (e.g. Escherichia coli).
  • Proper genus and species names are automatically recognized to apply specific breakpoints and define susceptibility categories.

Right:

Klebsiella pneumoniae, Acinetobacter baumannii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa (no reductions, corresponds to the official nomenclature)

Wrong:

K. pneumoniae, A. baumannii, P. aeruginosa (reductions are used)

After selecting the appropriate column name from the drop-down list, user can press the “Check Species Names” button for automatic checking.

After pressing the “Check Species Names” button a small table will appear with the names that fails the verification process (i.e. the names of microorganisms which were not recognized by the system). Then user should look through this table carefully:

  • If there are errors in some names (for example, a missing letter), user should correct the errors right in the editor window by double-clicking the necessary cell with the left mouse button and pressing the “Correct species names” button.
  • If there are no spelling errors, it means that there are no microorganisms with such names in the system. Such microorganisms are not excluded from the general data — analysis charts will also be built for them — only they will be colored not according to susceptibility categories, but in a solid gray color. If user works with his own S/I/R susceptibility categories, there will be no problem in identifying microorganism species.

If interpretation criteria for particular microorganism species have not been found, the system will try to apply criteria for the appropriate microorganism group.

Example. If Salmonella typhi criterias are not found, then Salmonella spp. criterias would be applied.

Date

  • This is a mandatory category.
  • Records without a date or with a varying date format will not be imported.

If all the dates are arranged correctly and uniformly, user (after selecting the corresponding header from the drop-down list) will see the time scale “Date Range Privew”. If the date format is not recognized with the Auto option, user should try to select one of the alternative formats:

  • 2018-12-31 (i.e. year-month-day)
  • 2018-31-12 (i.e. year-day-month)
  • 31-12-2018 (i.e. day-month-year)
  • 12-31-2018 (i.e. month-day-year)
Once user has selected the date format, he should check the box “Check if you see the time scale?".

Spatial Information

  • This is not a mandatory category.
  • There are two types of spatial information: “Geolocation” and “Longitude/Latitude Coordinates”.

Geolocations can include regions, such as countries and states, natural areas, cities and smaller locality types. The system will attempt to identify geolocations and find respective geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude) automatically. Optionally, user can check the box and select the columns containg the Longitude and Latitude values.

Please note that only the first 10 rows of the corresponding column are displayed to the user for preview.

Numeric Parameter

  • This is not a mandatory category.
  • As a numeric parameter, user can upload one of any continuous numeric variable, for example Age, Weight, etc.

User should check the corresponding box on the right side of the screen and select the table header form the drop-down list.

Please note that only the first 10 rows of the corresponding column are displayed to the user for preview.

Resistance Markers

  • This is not a mandatory category.
  • The total number of columns of this type is unlimited.

If there are column(s) containing information about Resistance Markers (resistance mechanisms, genes or mutations) that can be correlated with phenotypic resistance data, check the box and then select the respective column(s). Column header(s) will be used as name(s) of the Marker Groups.

Additional Parameters

  • This is not a mandatory category.
  • A maximum of 10 Parameter Columns can be selected.
  • Column titles will be used as names of the parameters.
  • Drag selected parameters to set their priority from 1 to 10.

Completing Step Two

To go to the next stage of the data import user should press the “Validate Step Two” button. It is recommended to review and double-check all the points of the current stage before saving.

item.title: Step 3 - Geocode
item.description:
Geocoding is an important step in creating a basis with which AMRcloud builds various maps and pins geographic markers.

Regions, cities and even separate hospital departments can be used as geographical objects in AMRcloud.

General Information

In order to start the geocoding process you should press the “1.Geocode it” button. This process takes some time, so user should wait for the system to put coordinates in the table below and for markers to appear in the map preview window.

In order to open the map preview, user should press the header of the “Map: preview” blue panel.

After the user is sure that all markers with coordinates are placed correctly, he should press the “Validate Step Three” button and proceed to the next import stage.

If Location(s) Is Not Found

If AMRcloud didn't recognize the geographical object (didn't put coordinates next to its name), user should check the correctness of the name of the geographical object. If there are errors in the name(s), it is necessary to correct the data in the source data table, to reset all import steps, and to upload the newly corrected version.

If there are no errors in the names of geographical objects, user should manually set the coordinates. To do it he should enter the corresponding coordinates in the right table (orange panel “Location(s) not found”) and press the button “Fix Coordinates”.

How to Get the Coordinates

User can get the coordinates of the required geographical objects using the preview map.

. To do it, user should zoom in on a geographical object and click on it with the left mouse button. The object's Latitude and Longtitude will be displayed below the map. After determining the object's coordinates, user should copy and paste them into the corresponding fields. . If user doesn't know the exact location of the geographical object on the map, he can use search string on the map and then left-click the object. .

Incorrect Marker's Position

The AMRcloud system may not automatically recognize user's geographical objects. For example, instead of St. Petersburg, Russia, system may pin St. Petersburg, Florida, USA. Therefore, user should carefully check the preview map before saving the results of the geocoding stage.

If user wants to correct the position of the marker on the map, he should:

  1. Click with the left mouse button on the required cell in the green table.
  2. Press the “Edit Coordinates” button.
  3. Edit the coordinates in the orange table.
  4. Press the “Fix Coordinates” button.

Local Objects

If user often works with his specific set of local geographical objects, he can save the coordinates of these local objects for future automatic use. For this purpose after editing coordinates in orange table, user should check the box “Save coordinates for future usage”. So the geographical coordinates will be permanently assigned to the corresponding name of the geographical object and will be saved in the user account. At subsequent downloads, the coordinates of objects with the same names will be automatically geocoded.

item.title: Step 4 - Determine S/I/R
item.description: First of all, at this stage user should choose the interpretation criteria from the drop-down list and press the “Interpret MIC and Disk Diffusion data” button. After the table with the interpretation statuses appears below, user can press the button “Complete All Steps” and finish the data import process.
